title: Why Won't My Airpods Charge? Troubleshooting Guide

steps.title: Reinsert the AirPod in the charging case.
steps.content: Reinsert the AirPod in the charging case. If your AirPod isn’t fully connected to the case, it won’t charge. Pull your AirPod out and quickly place it back in. Make sure it sits firmly in place and doesn’t move around.

steps.title: Clean your AirPod and the charging case.
steps.content: Clean your AirPod and the charging case. Check the charging connector on the bottom of your AirPod for any visible debris. Use a slightly damp lint-free cloth to wipe the AirPod clean, and then dry it off with a towel. If the case is dirty , shake out any debris from inside the charging ports before putting your AirPods back in. [1] X Research source For stubborn debris, clean your AirPods with isopropyl alcohol to get more cleaning power. Apple recommends avoiding putting anything inside the charging ports, including toothpicks or Q-tips, to prevent damage.

steps.title: Plug the case in while charging your AirPods.
steps.content: Plug the case in while charging your AirPods. Use the cord that came with your AirPods case for the best results. Plug the cord into the port on the bottom of the case and connect the other end to a wall adapter. Leave your AirPods for 5-10 minutes to see if they charge. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Unpair and re-pair your AirPods.
steps.content: Unpair and re-pair your AirPods. Place your AirPods in their case. Open Settings and select Bluetooth from the list. Find your AirPods on your connected devices and tap the info button next to their name. Select Forget This Device and confirm to disconnect your AirPods . [3] X Research source To pair your AirPods , just open the case and hold it near your device. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Try turning off Optimized Battery Charging.
steps.content: Try turning off Optimized Battery Charging. Optimized Battery Charging normally slows the charger down to prevent wear on the batteries, but some users have had issues with a glitch in the settings. To turn off the feature: [5] X Research source Open Settings and select Bluetooth . Tap on the info button next to your AirPods. Deselect Optimized Battery Charging .

steps.title: Update your AirPods’ firmware.
steps.content: Update your AirPods’ firmware. If your firmware is out of date, it may cause charging issues. Put your AirPods in their case and keep them near a device that’s connected to wifi. The firmware will update automatically if a new version is available. [6] X Research source To check the firmware on your AirPods, go to Settings, select Bluetooth , and tap the info button next to your AirPods. Scroll to the About section to see the firmware version you’re using. The latest firmware versions for AirPods are: AirPods Pro 2: 7A305 AirPods Pro 1, AirPods 2 & 3: 6A326 AirPods 4: 7A304 AirPods 1: 6.8.8

steps.title: Reset your AirPods.
steps.content: Reset your AirPods. Start by putting your AirPods in their case and leaving them for at least 30 seconds. Go into your device's Bluetooth settings and unpair your AirPods so they’re disconnected. How you reset your AirPods depends on which variety you have. After you fully reset your AirPods, just open the case near your device to reconnect them. [7] X Research source AirPods 1, 2, and 3, or AirPods Pro: Open the lid and hold the button on the back of the case for 15 seconds until the light flashes amber, then white. AirPods 4: Open the lid and double-tap the button on the front of the case 3 times. A status light will flash amber and then white if you reset your AirPods correctly.

steps.title: Check for software updates on your device.
steps.content: Check for software updates on your device. Open the Settings app on your device and select General from the list. Then, tap on Software Update to see if there are any available. If your device is outdated, let the updates run and install completely before trying to use your AirPods again.

steps.title: Contact Apple support or visit an Apple Store.
steps.content: Contact Apple support or visit an Apple Store. If none of the fixes work for your AirPods, there may be an issue with the hardware or the internal pieces. Contact your local Apple Store or an authorized provider to let them know your issues. They may be able to repair damage, or they may be able to order a replacement. If your AirPods are covered by AppleCare or AppleCare+, then repairs or replacements only cost a small incident fee of around $29 USD.

steps.title: The charger connection is blocked or dirty.
steps.content: The charger connection is blocked or dirty. The metal pieces at the end of each AirPod sit in the bottom of the case and make contact with the charging ports. If there’s any debris or mess on either piece, then the loose connection can prevent the battery from charging.

steps.title: Your AirPods case isn’t charged.
steps.content: Your AirPods case isn’t charged. The case usually has enough battery to provide a few full charges for your AirPods, but they may not charge at all if the battery is low. Putting your AirPods in an uncharged case will keep them protected, but they won’t gain any more battery life. Charge the case regularly so it can recharge your AirPods.

steps.title: There is a hardware or software issue.
steps.content: There is a hardware or software issue. Apple regularly rolls out new firmware updates for AirPods and software updates for devices to correct glitches and known problems. If you’re using an outdated device or AirPods, then it’s more likely to cause issues with charging or listening.

steps.title: The AirPod is damaged.
steps.content: The AirPod is damaged. James Bell, a phone repair specialist, notes that the internal components of AirPods are really simple and easily damaged. He says, “The battery is a very common failure…and the battery can fail in one but not the other.”

steps.title: How do you charge AirPods quickly?
steps.content: How do you charge AirPods quickly? Plug your case into a wall adapter or computer for the fastest charging. After about 5-15 minutes, your AirPods should have enough battery to last you for a couple of hours. If you have Optimized Battery Charging on, it may hold your AirPods at 80% charge to prevent battery wear. Try turning this setting off to ensure your AirPods fully charge when you want to use them.

steps.title: How do you check the charge status on your AirPods?
steps.content: How do you check the charge status on your AirPods? When your AirPods are plugged in and connected to your phone, keep the case closed and hold it near your device. Your AirPods will appear with the current battery levels. [8] X Research source Alternatively, add the Batteries widget to your home screen to easily glance at the battery levels. If you don’t see a lightning bolt icon underneath your AirPods, they aren’t properly charging. Take them out and try one of the fixes listed above.

steps.title: Why does one AirPod lose battery faster than the other?
steps.content: Why does one AirPod lose battery faster than the other? If you chat on the phone or if you have “Hey Siri” turned on, the microphone in your AirPod may drain the battery more quickly . Even though both AirPods have microphones, only one is used at a time, so it may drain more quickly on one side. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Why is my AirPods case not charging?
steps.content: Why is my AirPods case not charging? The charging port on your AirPods case may be dirty or damaged. Try using an Apple-branded cord or the one that came with your AirPods to charge. Use a dry toothbrush to get rid of any debris that may be caught inside the port. [10] X Research source

steps.title: How long do AirPods last?
steps.content: How long do AirPods last? Bell states that even though AirPods are well-designed, they’re not meant to last more than 2-3 years before the amplifier inside starts to go out or until a piece gets damaged.
